description: From Latin vitiātus, the perfect passive participle of vitiō (“damage, spoil”), from vitium (“vice”).

verbs.description: vitiate (third-person singular simple present vitiates, present participle vitiating, simple past and past participle vitiated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To spoil, make faulty; to reduce the value, quality, or effectiveness of something.
examples: The least admixture of a lie, -- for example, the taint of vanity, the least attempt to make a good impression, a favorable appearance, -- will instantly vitiate the effect.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make something ineffective, to invalidate.
